Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2009 09:58AM pringles1 wrote: Hi, not usre if I will be of much help here. My implants are only two years old. and was dx in Feb 09. I am going with lumpectomy and rads. I had originally planned to replace the implant on the BC side because of all the information stating that rads and scar tissue, skin and breast tissue dont do well together, But as luck would have it, the valve broke so during my re-excision they took out the old  and placed a tissue expander in. My implandt was a 350cc they replace with a 400cc TC filled to 200  and at this point it is big. We are not filling it any more because we really dont want to do any more stretching than we have to. Which is good because i really dont want any more tension on the scars than needed. And you also hve to worry about capsular contracture  which is still a possiblily with the TE because the scar tissue is forming around it know .. I wont start my rads unil the end of May or beginin of June. Just had my latest surgery last week and I have to heal... But I would think if you had mastectomy withut radiation and your implants dont fail  during surgery they would stay in. Unless you want to go bigger, then they might do a TE until you heal and then put new implants in,  I just dont know. Talk with your BS and see what he says about it... he might recommend you to a PS he or she works with to get their opion.
Posts.Title: Anyone Have Implants prior to Diagnosis? yasminv1 danix5

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 10:27AM pringles1 wrote: Good on getting the second opinions.. you'll feel much better afterward. I don't feel that most microcalcifiations  become  cancer.  Most of them are not associated with cancer in any way shape or form  They can be from  previous injury, aging or just part of  breast changes that some women experience   And some are associated with cancer. They can usually but not always tell by the mammogram.. sometime it is a little hard to make out the difference between the two so,  its watch and wait or you go for biopsy to find out. As for my right side, no I am not worried with the calcification's I do have have this point,  they have been there for many years and haven't changed.. But it would unrealistic to say I don't wonder about any new ones that might show up in the future. I will cross that bridge when I come to it. Wasn't offered the mastectomy,  Mine was located in just one area and was handled by the two surgeries I did have,.But there are many other factors to consider in making that choice .. I hope you get the answers your looking for  and that your calicifications are classifed as nothing to worry about!...((HUGS)).
Posts.Title: detecting a lump when you have implants? keljam1 Cris30

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 04:02AM pringles1 wrote: Its been a while since Ive last glanced through the boards.. Stage one, done with rads ( JULY) on Tomaxifen.. Next month will be my 6 month follow up mammo ( kinda nervous about that)... and then follwed by tissue expander/implant swap in late Jan or ealry Feb.... Feb will be my one year out from diagnosis celebration.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 05:39AM pringles1 wrote: Mine was found on a mammogram as calcification's..  had no lump formation.. caught it very early..if you do you BSE every month you will become familiar with your breast and be able to spot or pinpoint something new or doesn't feel right continue with that, mammos and what ever else your primary care/GP/ or GYN suggest.. Having implants does obscure some of the angles and make it a little harder to interpret.. but from my experience having implants does not make it any more difficult to find lumps.
Posts.Title: detecting a lump when you have implants? keljam1 Cris30

Posts.Content: May 15, 2009 08:12PM pringles1 wrote: keljam1- before I had implants I had calcification's on my right breast since I was 35 (*GP ordered mamo because I had dense breast).. my left side was clear.... right side hasn't changed at all. ( I am now 51). this past Jan had my usual yearly.. thats when they found the calcification's on left.. was told at that time by radiologist I should have it biopsied, (that was followed up by a letter). had follow up with BS and set up stereotatic biopsy which found DCIS, followed by lumpectomy/excisional biopsy which found IDC in the mist of it As you can see they can either watch ( as in my right-which they are still following) or act (as in my left),,You can always ask for a second opinion the reading if your not pleased with the answer or information given to you  or if you just don't feel right about it.Get recommendations to a good BS and talk to him/her about it and if you feel you still want the biopsy let them know. .Being pro active is your best bet when it comes to your health and peace of mind!
Posts.Title: detecting a lump when you have implants? keljam1 Cris30
